instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
Hey! 

I'm new here but I have been [I][B]trying [/B][/I]to troubleshoot boards for a while. I have this board in that has an orange light but does not turn on, no fan spin. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is showing 8.56v on both sides of f7140. I found a cap that was askew [<CAPACITOR>C7094</CAPACITOR>] and replaced it. Before doing so, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> was showing around 1.8V on pin 2 of L7095, now <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is showing 3.335v on the same pin. 

Not sure where to go from here, i could really use some help. Thank you!

As a side note, are there any resources someone can point me to to break down the sleep states for macbooks? Just trying to wrap my head around the logical progression from initial power to boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and PCH's RTC signals.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/G3_to_S3_State_for_Ivy_Bridge_Haswell_and_Broadwell[/URL]

Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: Thank you! Ill post them when i get back in my shop on tuesday. In the mean time, im off to study :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.335v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 3.309v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>: 3.03v but drops to 2.8 temporarily
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 3.352v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.356v

PCH RTC: I may need some guidance on this, what signals do i need to check for? Im not sure if my meter is sufficient enough to measure clock signals, and since I have not measured clock signals before, I'm not sure if I'm doing it correctly (each probe on the terminals of the oscillator). In this case, am i checking <SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX1</SIGNAL> against ground on my Hz setting on my meter?

I've got a Klein Tools MM400.

 Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
I meant DC voltage of RTC signals.
RTC clock isn't needed there (yet).
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> comes on too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>:3.24v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>:3.27v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>:2.06v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>:2.77v
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>:3.33v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: yes it does

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> should pulse at same time; check that.
If catch it, check at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> too.

Worth to try SMC bypass too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: Will check / give that a try when I'm back in office. really appreciate your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is at 0.0mv without power button 
does that indicate short on that line?

Not sure if this is relevant, but <RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR> shows 0.483v on pin 2 diode mode

not surprisingly, SMC bypass did not work, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: I asked if you catch any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> [B][U]when[/U][/B] pressing power button (at same time).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: oh my bad, i thought it was brought to logic low like the other. No it does not change with power button

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
Then seems to have a PCH related issue.

"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>:2.06v"
Force this signal soldering 100K instead of 1M (<RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.1v
pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and none on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> still

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
Be sure <SIGNAL>1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> is present.

You can try heating PCH area untill 200 degress Celsius, for 20-30s aprox.
No need to melt the balls; the idea is to burn eventually accumulated crap.
Use quality flux!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1.06v

Should I leave the underfill?

threads.message: Is better to clean it, at least on the PCH's corners.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: No luck, anything else I should try?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: constant 3.1v drops to 2.7v with power button

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
Should be stable always.
Check what happens removing <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>: 3.27v drops to 2.91v with power button

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
putting it back on, again reads 3.27v drops to 2.8v with power

oem original charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
Board doesn't try to turn on without <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>?
No pulse at all at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?
In such case, bad PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: Nothing.. Thanks for the help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message: If you wouldn't mind, would you care to briefly explain why you had me test all of those lines? I have been following along with the tree that you sent at the beginning, but hearing it directly may help me understand even better.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Orange Light, No Power
threads.message:
PCH requires some basic signals and voltages, in order to start power on sequence.
In fact, it doesn't reply to power button at all.
All previous checks assured that PCH receives all these.
